questions.text: Which of the following statements about "Stochastic effect" of radiation is CORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: Severity of effect is a function of dose

options.label: B
options.text: Probability of effect is a function of dose

questions.correct_answer: B. Probability of effect is a function of dose
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Probability of effect is a function of dose Stochastic effects means "Chance Effects"

Highyeild:

> Stochastic effects occur by chance, It has no threshold dose - It is independent of dose > The probability of effect increases with dose > The severity of the effect is independent of the dose received

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - OPTION A,C are incorrect statements related to Stochastic effects

Extraedge:

Stochastic effect is those effects which occur when a person receives a high dose of radiation . These effects have an increased probability of occurrence with increased dose . There is no threshold dose below which is creatively certain that a stochastic effect cannot occur.

questions.text: Acute Hematological syndrome occurs at an exposure of?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2 Gy Acute hematological syndrome occurs at an exposure of 1-2 Gy

Highyeild:

> In Acute hematological syndrome (AHC), depletion of blood cells like RBC, WBC, Platelet occurs due to irradiation to entire body by high dose of radiation over a short period of time (usually in minutes) > Primary cause of death is infection and hemorrhage > Most deaths occur within a few months after exposure

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - CORRECT answer is 2Gy,hence all other options are ruled out.

Extraedge:

Acute Radiation Syndrome (ARS) (sometimes known as radiation toxicity or radiation sickness) is an acute illness caused by irradiation of the entire body (or most of the body) by a high dose of penetrating radiation in a very short period of time (usually a matter of minutes).

questions.text: Which of the following is SI unit of Radiation exposure?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Coulomb/kg > Coulomb/kg is the SI unit of Radiation exposure

Highyeild:

> Conventional unit of Radiation exposure is Roentgen > One Roentgen = 2.58x10-4 C/kg > Gray = SI unit of absorbed dose Rad = Conventional unit of absorbed dose

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Rad -Conventional unit of absorbed dose Option: B. Gray - SI unit of absorbed dose Option: D. Roentgen - 2.58x10-4 C/kg

Extraedge:

The radiation dose absorbed by a person (that is, the amount of energy deposited in human tissue by radiation) is measured using the conventional unit rad or the SI unit gray (Gy). The biological risk of exposure to radiation is measured using the conventional unit rem or the SI unit sievert (Sv)

questions.text: Which of the following cell is most sensitive to radiation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lymphocyte > Lymphocytes (White blood cells) are most sensitive to radiation because these cells are constantly regenerating (undergo cell divisions) they have the highest nucleus to cytoplasm ratio of all blood cells .

Highyeild:

> Reproductive and gastrointestinal cells are not regenerating as quickly and are less sensitive > The nerve and muscle cells are the slowest to regenerate and are the least sensitive cells > Platelets are least sensitive among Blood cel ls

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Neutrophil - are less sensitive than Lymphocyte Option: C. Basophil - are less sensitive than Lymphocyte Option: D. Platelets -least sensitive among Blood cells

Extraedge:

The blood forming cells were one of the most sensitive cells due to their rapid regeneration rate, the blood forming organs are one of the most sensitive organs to radiation. Muscle and nerve cells were relatively insensitive to radiation, and therefore, so are the muscles and the brain.

questions.text: Thermoluminescent Dosemeter badge is used for?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Personal dose monitoring > TLD badge is used for Personal Dose Monitoring > TLD badge measures the radiation dose received by any individuals

Highyeild:

> TLD is made up of : Calcium Sulfate (CaS04) and Lithium fluoride (LiF) > TLD has 3 number of Discs It is to be worn inside the lead apron

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Radiographic film exposure- TLD badge NOT used Option: C. X-ray tube efficiency - TLD badge not used Option: D. Patient dose measurement -TLD badge is used for Personal Dose Monitoring

Extraedge:

Thermoluminescent dosimeter ( TLD ) is a passive radiation detection device that is used for personal dose monitoring or to measure patient dose. Parts plastic holder nickel-coated aluminum card with TLD discs the discs are made of a thermoluminescent material, commonly calcium sulphate doped with dysprosium (CaSO4:Dy) or lithium fluoride (LiF) nearly tissue equivalent, although not at all x-ray energies 1 the discs are 0.8 mm thick and have a 1.35 cm diameter three filters against each disc top: aluminum and copper middle: perspex lower: open

questions.text: The ALARA principle applies to what aspect of Radiology?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Radiation safety > ALARA principle applies to Radiation safety aspects of radiology > ALARA stands for AS LOW AS REASONABLY ACHIEVABLE

Highyeild:

Three fundamental principles of ALARA are : Time Distance Shielding

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - ALARA principle is not used for OPTION A,B,D

Extraedge:

ALARA stands for “as low as reasonably achievable”. ALARA means avoiding exposure to radiation that does not have a direct benefit to you, even if the dose is small. To do this, you can use three basic protective measures in radiation safety: time, distance, and shielding.
